We spent about 45 minutes watching the gorillas and even saw the big male chase down one of the females and pound his chest. Wow! The rest of the zoo was OK. We were fortunate to be there on a nice day and enjoyed ourselves. All the enclosures are well kept and the animals seem to be well cared for. The food was OK; we were there during the off-season so we didn't have many choices. But definitely try some of the Dutch poffertjes (mini pancakes). The staff were exceptionally friendly. A great day out for the family - or for something different to do in Amsterdam.

Zoo in the city!. There is so much to see at the Artis Royal Zoo! I totally didn't regret visiting this zoo at all (true, we have a zoo too in Singapore). This zoo has much more animals than I would have found at the zoo back home. You need at least 2-3 hours to tour all the sites but might end up spending more time there so be prepared!

Expensive, but some good bits.. Visited zoo yesterday, €18.95 each to get in and they charge you €2 for a map, which I thought was disgusting.Best bits were the sea lions feeding, the butterfly house and the baby elephant :), lots of beautiful butterfly's very close up, and very interesting to see baby elephant with the mother.The lion enclosure had one lion, two lionesses and a baby, great viewing, but VERY small enclosure, for these animals.All in all a large zoo, good animals, but expensive for a few hours.

A hidden jewel in Amsterdam. As someone who tries to visit the zoo at whatever destination I go to, this zoo was a cut above most inner-city zoos. Even though it was winter and some of the animals were off display so their habitats could be repaired, the whole place was full of interesting creatures, pleasing layouts, fantastic exhibits and lots of information available in English. A must-see for anyone in the city traveling with children! The outstanding aquarium was one of the best parts of the whole zoo.

Great zoo. The zoo was excellent but as incorrectly pointed out in a previous review IS NOT A FREE ATTRACTION the zoo had a great selection of animals however due to the cold not all of the animals were out and about, so vistiting in summer would probably be a better idea. Also would of been better if they had more than 1 show a day for the sealions. We went at 11 - 2 and there wasn't one on til 4ish but after seeing all the animals a few times we didnt want to wait around all day.
The oldest city in The Netherlands. Good location, perfect conditions for inhabitants and visitors.

Pleasant day out. We visited Artis on a frosty Sunday with friends with a small baby. Despite the cold the zoo was well worth the visit. With small walks between covered (heated) attractions were perfect for this cold day. With snow and freezing temperatures some of the animals were kept in their housing. Despite of that there is plenty to see. Cold was actually a good thing as never seen big cats this active. The zoo in nice and compact but still plenty to see. Restrooms and lunch cafe were clean and organized and everyone in our party had a great afternoon.
Relaxing in the Zoo. Love the zoo with all the animals and especially the Butterfly Hall

A Nice zoo. We visited the zoo in December 2011, using the I Amsterdam card Discount. Hindsight when we picked up our 2012 book, the zoo is now a FREE attraction. Hmm. Oh Well. Would certainly recommend as a result if visiting Amsterdam to get the Card!We Visited the Zoo 2 years ago, and In fact not too much has changed since that time. It was unfortunately raining lightly when we visited, but there are a number of indoor areas so that wasn't too much of a problem.The Usual Suspects are on display, There was an unusual Monkey 'Pyramid' with small Baboons? Clambering over it.The Chimpanzee had quite a few friendly Chimps. In fact 2 were getting, em, overly friendly? with each other!The Butterfly house had a number of colourful Butterflies flitting about. The aquarium was actually better than I expected. I'm not a big 'fish' fan but the tanks were well displayed and had a good selection of wildlife on display.I have mixed views about the bear enclosure. The bear was roaming about, but as with most big animals in captivity, seemed less than happy.The Lion enclosure was a different story though, a happy pride of lions with a 'teenage' cub causing chaos. Certainly memorable.The monkey house has most of the smaller monkeys indoors. I managed to annoy the staff as I stood on what appeared to be a poured concrete path to get a better view. It seems it was actually a fountain. Oops! Perhaps someone should tell them fountains usually have water though!We ate in the 2 Cheetahs cafe. Very nice food. And just before leaving had a Coffee in the Cafe by the entrance, again nice.We didn't try the Planetarium this time, due to time constraints, but in half a day covered most of the Zoo.Worth a visit certainly, but check what offers are available first!
stayed by here. stayed in hortus hotel right next door to the zoo!walking down the street makes you feel your in a mary poppins movie with the quiet streets lined with trees! lovely birds

Loved my visit in Feb.. We had a great morning at this zoo and it was reasonably quiet in Feb as it was freezing outside. Good thing about this zoo was we spent most of the time indoors , fish, butterflys , etc. All the monkeys were inside to getting some heat. The only complaint was there was not a big choice of food, maybe because of the time of year.I would go again.
Interesting!. Big zoo, with different places for each species. Expensive food.
Beautiful old Zoo. The elephants were well hung the day we walked around....my girlfriend was deeply impressed and inspired. Thank goodness for handicap-sized bathroom stalls to drop a load...
Visit Amsterdam Zoo!!. There's so much to see, you should go early so you have enough time to walk around.

Amazing! Too much to see!. We went to Artis Zoo on the last day before we left Amsterdam.We went at lunchtime for a few hours before our flight only to find there was so much there you could easily spend all day there. We went in the winter when the weather was terrible but still had a really enjoyable time. You can spend a whole day there and not get bored. We rushed around the exhibits to try and make sure we saw everything in the small amount of time we had.Make sure you get a map so that you can go to see the animals you want to see the most.The price was €18.50 per adult ticket and was very reasonable as there is so much to see.There is a Planetarium, Aquarium, Butterfly house, Insectarium, Aviary, as well as all of the other many animals to see. There are elephants, gorillas, giraffes, bears, monkeys, reptiles and lots more.The butterfly house was incredible. It was a heated greenhouse where there were butterflies everywhere. You're not supposed to touch the butterflies but there were loads of people with butterflies sitting on them.We didn't manage to make it to the Planetarium but will have to go next time we visit. There is a big cafe and shop so that you can stop and take a break.I'd definitely recommend visiting the zoo to anyone, especially families with kids.

Amsterdam's best kept secret for the family. Last Sunday, my husband, 4-year old daughter, 6-week old daughter and I went to visit Artis Zoo. I have always been intrigued to go here since there seemed to have been a lot of animal births in 2011. In fact, if you travel by Schiphol, you won't fail to notice the huge Artis Zoo poster advert of an elephant fetus waiting to be born at the baggage claim area!The zoo is an excellent place to spend the day if you have children bursting with energy! Artis Zoo is small enough to see in a day, the opening hours are very kind to parents who need to find an activity from 9am onwards. In the summer, the zoo stays open till sunset (on other days only until 5pm).Definitely plenty to see and enjoy outdoors: camels, elephants, vultures, mountain goats, primates, birds, giraffes, big cats. Indoors, you have the aquarium, the seals underwater, the butterflies, the insectarium and the reptilium. I also found that the Artis Zoo is very kind to families who chance upon inclement weather during their visit. There is enough roofed attractions to still enjoy the zoo even if it's too cold or raining.Compared to other family attractions in the Netherlands, the food in eating establishments in the zoo (the Planetarium cafe and the the Two Cheetahs) were decent. The Planetarium cafe is right by the entrance serving simple sandwiches, however, if you want something heftier, head straight to the Two Cheetahs near the children's playground. You can let the children burn some energy during/after the meal break.Last but not the least, this is no tourist trap. I am glad that I did not spend a single cent during my visit on a useless souvenir :0). So this one is great as well for those on a budget. Be aware though, the entrance fee is 18€+ for adults and 15€ for children 4 and over. Consider going as a group if you prefer to pay less!Have fun!

Not the best zoo, not the worst.. Zoo's can be amazing or depressing. Artis is definitely not the best by far, in fact the size of the cages of some animals were depressing to watch. Then again, after the amazing Singapore zoo, I may be spoiled for life...

Very good, back in it's days. Artis is still very popular, but it is actually very dated. It opened in the early 1800's and it shows. The animals have cramped shelters, and it actually looks like the bigger the animal, the less space he gets. Upside is you can get close to them, but if you just take a good look at the surroundings, you can't get passed the fact that a Zoo should be sheltering it's animals in better places.

2nd best zoo in Europe. I loved the fact that the animals had enough room to move and feel as close to the "real life" as possible in these conditions. The selection of animals is big: from little colorful fish in the aquarium to majestetic elephants. One can seriously spend a whole day walking around there, see when and how different animals are being feed and enjoy the escape from the city. Depending on the time of the year, there are different activities for the children and small cafes (and a restaurant) to buy food, drinks and snacks. There is only one other zoo in Europe where I have been to that has better conditions (and wider selection of animals) is in Edinburgh.
Small Zoo. Compared to Blijdorp you feel awful for those caged animals

Best Zoo per square meter. Artis is one of the smallest zoos in the world, in sheer size. This is because the animals are kept closer together than in any other zoo I've ever seen. The result is: you walk less and see more animals than anywhere else. Very convenient for kids, for the elderly, or anyone else who does not enjoy those very long walks you are required to do just to go between the lions and the apes (not to mention all other animals in the place.

Expensive, but a good day out if you have young children. I actually walked to the zoo from central station and didn't think it was far at all. But there are trams that take you literally right to the zoo, i believe they are trams 9 and 14, if I remember correctly.The zoo didn't have no grand sign or entrance so I found it simpy y following the people. I personally thought that the cost of the ticket was very high at 18.95 euros for a normal tourist. Plus 1.99 euros if you want a map of the zoo. I would recommend the map as it is quite a large maze like zoo and I missed out on seeing some animals, definitely the baby elephant.I haven't visited many zoo's so cant really compare this to others. The Artis zoo did have a large variety of animals, sea life and insects. As a solo traveller I spent 5 hours very easily at the zoo, so if you have young children I would allow more time. I found that most of the animals were very sedentary so I didn't really get to see much. But they have a good selection from giraffes, to bears, to jaguars to monkeys.The aquarium was decent, nothing special if you have been to an aquarium before, and definitely nothing compared to the amazing Barcelona aquarium, butstill worth a visit.The parts I found really impressive were the gorilla enclosure, the gorillas are really active and put on a great show. Also the butterfly enclosure was pretty cool, as you have all these colourful butterflies flapping away right next to you if not on you. I don't know what a planetarium has to do with a zoo, but this zoo has one and being the first time for me in a planetarium I absolutely loved it.Overall, it is a bit pricey, but i'ts something different from the usual Amsterdam, which is museums, girls and weed, this is something the whole family can enjoy. After strolling through the whole zoo, visit the planetarium right at the end as you get to lie down and watch the show, so an awesome way to rest too!

Brilliant zoo. I loved this zoo. It had such a diverse range of animals and a huge collection of birds. If you want to enjoy this zoo though, make sure you go early in the day as there is quiet a lot of it to see, including the various animal houses. A lizard in the reptile house escaped while we were there and I loved that. I thought it was a nice touch by the lizard to make my experience unique. We told the zoo keepers and they turned up swiftly and returned him to his home.

Not the best, but a nice zoo anyway. We spent a few hours in the Zoo in Amsterdam, not like the Zoo of my hometown, but smaller (more compact) which makes sense if you imagine that it is in the center of Amsterdam!. Artis is an old zoo, which is being renovated, but they don't have much space to expend... it has a nice variety of animals, what we liked most were the Lemur Island (where they walked free and the people could enter it and see them up close), the newly made african plains.. nice place to get a drink and sit on the terrace and the African lions, their enclosure needs to be renovated, but i just loved the sight of these majestic and in good shape animals... the male lions must be in the prime of his life!.There are some nice green areas... a good zoo for a few hours/ not a whole day!.
Spent a whole day here. This zoo is really big and there are lot's of different animals. We spent all day here and it was fun.

One of the better zoos I've been to!. Love the layout of the zoo, it's actually quite big. I went in the fall and it was beautiful. They had a baby elephant, baby giraffe and baby monkeys. Who doesn't love babies. What I loved most about the zoo, is the animals seemed to be genuinely enjoying themselves. I am torn on the idea of zoos and keeping animals in cages, so I go back and forth. They all seemed well fed and given plenty of activities within their confines. You also have the ability to get very close to the animals, which you can't do at a lot of zoos. Butterfly pavilion was very cool, too.

nice to get away from the city. Even though there are lots of families with little kids, it's still nice to get away from the city. We've been many times now and I love to see the animals at different times. We always go to the Kune Kune pigs in the pet zoo, as they are so much fun to see.
Brilliant. Loely zoo- loas of animals, only downside was it rained & therefore some of the animals went inside where we couldn't see them.
Bit pricey, but worth it.. We enjoyed a good 3-4 hours at the zoo. It's a proper old school zoo with an amazing aquarium. Bit pricey, but worth it.

Brilliant Zoo. Loved visiting this zoo it was winter so wasnt busy at all but its massive compared to some of the zoos here in britian, if u have kids its great as they have all different kinds of animals and there is lots of space to run around. would go back on next visit to amsterdam

Great time @ Artis Zoo. This is a lovely Zoo just outside Amsterdam and very easy to get to by tram!! Nice and relaxed plenty of animals to see, follow the map and time it right for feeding times (Lions, Seals etc) Make sure and try the Poffertjes at the coffee shop beside the kids play park, these are like mini pancakes oh so tasty :) We would visit it again!
Very upsetting. For a developed country, the zoo was in a terrible state. The enclousers were small and the animals looked unhappy

Very pleasant surprise. I normally dislike zoos, but this one was a very nice one. It was a lot of joys in displays, the animal most happy, I think we saw all those we were interested in. The lemurs were probably most fun.

Lovely old Zoo in the center of Amsterdam. We expected an old Zoo with small cages, but went anyway as the weather was nice and we wanted to do something outdoors. We were pleasantly surprised, the Zoo apparently is undergoing some changes, because we didn't see a lot of unhappy animals in small cages instead we saw a zoo where most animals looked to be ok (although the leopard and jaguar didn't seem to be too happy). We have seen Zoo's with smaller cages where the animals looked in much worse conditions than this one. The Zoo has a small parc with statues where you can sit and also another area next to the canal.. ideal to sit on the terrace and eat and drink something. We most liked the lemurs running and jumping around freely, the lions with their small cub and gorillas.For us a nice day out, well three hours outdoors in the sun!.

Lovely zoo. Beautiful layout and space.. As the title says, the zoo was laid out beautifully with lots of park spaces inbetween exhibits. We saw a few animals we'd never seen before and all the exhibits looked nice and spacious and the animals looked well looked after! The weather was lovely when we went and the food stalls and restaurants were all good quality and good prices. We spent about 3 hours there so it isnt a full day activity but just jump on a tram and youre soon in dam square where theres plenty to do!
Brilliant day. We had a brilliant day weather was fab and seeing all the animals was great. De twee cheetas resturant was yummy and not to dear.

One of the best I've visited. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Artis Zoo here in Amsterdam yesterday. I would rate it as one of the best we have ever visited and congratulate the team there for the wonderful attraction they have set up. So much to see and do and I would disagree with the comments on other posts which state it as cramped and animals distressed, total rubbish. The Aquarium was fascinating, really well laid out with plenty to see, I was really impressed (there is a lift for wheelchair users to access the 2nd floor). The Butterfly house was stunning, got some fantastic close up photos of some beautiful butterflies, well worth going into. Plenty of other animals to see close up too, Monkeys, Elephants, Lions, Giraffes, Zebras, Seals, the list goes on!. There seemed to be plenty of kids activities too if you are taking your kids to the zoo. Nice clean toilets dotted around the park for visitors. All in all I would highly recommend a visit here when in Amsterdam, and I was quite surprised to see that the zoo didnt rate higher on Tripadvisor

Small but very up close and clean. The zoo was not as big as I am used to but awesome never the less ..... very clean and quite ... and no bikes to dodge ... it did rain but things were still out and moving all of the out buildings were open and we did it all .... a great place to spend the afternoon...... kids will love just how up close and open the displays are. ..... we took a snack with us and had lunch there in the gardens very nice and peaceful ..... also we grabbed a bike taxi to get there and back that was a fun ride in itself.... If in amsterdam make it a point to visit the zoo .....

A great day out. First things first, before going to the zoo I read the reviews on here and im sorry but all those saying the space is small and the animals are distressed must of had too much of the green stuff.The zoo was in excellent condition and at no point where any if the animals showing any sign of distress. I have been to many European zoos and this has been the best zoo I have ever been to. The level of car to ensure the best possible quality animal welfare was clear for all to see. The zoo prides itself on being one of the worlds best zoos for conservation and breeding. I love animals and would nor of stayed of the zoo was not up to spec, but it was more than I could ever imagine. They are currently in the process of making the zoo even bigger and are enlarging the areas further.It was a great day out, prices for food etc are not cheap like most zoos but they encourage you to take a picnic and there is plenty of seating all over the zoo.If you have young children there are little pull carts for your child to use so it makes it fun for the whole family.The trip to Artiz was the highlight of our holiday and will be going back for sure.

interesting, pleasant surroundings, but cramped in places. we used a tram to get here & found the zoo easily. If you have an attraction card from your hotel reception for a free souvenir, it's a free map worth €2, so don't buy along with your entrance ticket. Entry is €14 which we thought a bit pricey but we got discount using the I Amsterdam card.We perhaps missed some of the animals due to the weather conditions, but we thought some if the enclosures a bit small & limiting. The bars in the cages are so thick it was impossible to get a decent photo.Thoroughly enjoyed the seals & the aquarium. We had lunch in the two cheetahs restaurant & found the prices very reasonable, not very disabled friendly though, toilets were downstairs & stairs a bit steep. Also there were a lot of children running about which I don't approve of in a restaurant.The shop is very child oriented, not much for adults. Toilets very clean & plentiful as we're seated areas.

Excellent zoo with lots of space and relaxed environment. Having been to many zoos across Europe and S Africa, I find the zoo in Amsterdam to be the best in class. It has lots of space, very relaxed environment, well maintained infrastructure and beautiful surroundings.I spent around 4 hours and could have easily spent 4 more. If possible, I will like to go again.Everything except the pricing of tickets was great.
Best Aquariums i have ever seen. Meerkats, chimps< Lions, lemurs, elephants, seals, butterflys, this zoo has it all. The only thing Amsterdam doesnt have is a beach.
A lovely time. The staff were ok generally. The attractions were excellent and it was hard to fit everything in which is good. The only downside is that there should be a family ticket available.
Amazing!. Amazing zoo. With lots of animals. Very clean everywhere. You must visit the zoo if you go to Amsterdam

Excellent reptile house, aquarium and butterfly exhibition...the rest is poor, sparse, sad and sometimes cruel. First things first, the reptile house, aquarium and butterfly sections of Artis Zoo are truly excellent – a MUST see, but probably not worth the expense, as a general admission ticket is required.The rest of the zoo is poor – definitely agree with some of the comments about the questionable conditions in which some of the animals are housed. I am NOT a massive animal lover by any means, but in my opinion, many enclosures – particularly the ‘big cats’ and the bears – appear quite small and cramped, and some of the animals don’t do much other than pace back and forth constantly. We also saw a penguin that was quite clearly injured (looked like a broken wing), lying around looking quite forlorn and sad.  Many of the animals didn’t come ‘out’ so that they could be seen, but instead hidden away in their ‘bed’ areas, and the majority of the bird enclosures were quite literally totally empty.Added to that, the zoo is rather dilapidated, with large enclosures containing no animals at all, a lot of footpaths cordoned off, and staff very thin on the ground. Sad for the animals living in poor conditions, and also quite boring even looking at the animals that appeared to be better housed.Quite a sad sight in a major city like Amsterdam – would not visit again.

In the citycentre. The zoo is located near the citycentre of amsterdam. It's easy to rech with public transport, Number 9 from central station to Waterlooplein.The admission fee is not very cheap, around 19 euro for an adult, but it's a big zoo.The aquaria area is really nice. The animals really don't look happy, maybe there cages are too small. I think the zoo needs an update.

A good half day. We went here for half a day. The zoo was pleasant enough, not that I am a fan of zoos. The crocodile is a must see as is the baby elephant.On leaving go to the Brouwerij 't IJ about 1 or 2 tramstops away !

A wonderful zoo,where the animals come first.. I visited Artis Zoo,in July 2011,again.As always,it is one of the cleanest zoos,I have ever visited.The staff are helpful and clearly enjoy their vocation.The animals including,the new born lion cub and elephant calf are housed well.If you see a long queue to get in,do not worry. I got to my cashier in 15 minutes and the queue was very long!!!

Superb. This visit was made half minded after reading the feedbacks and most of them appear now totally unrealistic. This zoo is wonderfully kept, animals are obviously well fed and in good form, according to glistening pelts, extremely active individuals (including a wide range of medusas, axotols, chimpanzees, sea lions, unusual (and magic!) butterflies; even the male lion was busy caring for his front paw) and the amount of babies of all kinds allover. I mean, animal babies i.e. giraffe, elephant, lemurs, monkeys, lion, otters, sea lions, birds, aso. Impossible to concur with any of the comments reporting bored animals in too small settlements. The XIX century settlements have been wonderfully preserved and enhanced.Being there at feeding time for sea lions, the tight relationship between the keeper and his tenants was witnessed as obvious and well maintained.A definite "must go" for animal lovers, not only children, while in Amsterdam, with the added convenience of extreme closeness to the wonderful city centre.

tiny cages, restless animals....... We went to this zoo and we were really impressed by the state of the cages. Dirty and small. It's a crime to keep lions, pumas and sealions in those small cages. wandering back'n forward in the same tracks all day long. Our kid was happy, but got sad and worried for the animals. Never again.

This zoo was such a delightful surprise!. Our hotel host had mentioned that we would enjoy visiting the Amsterdam Zoo and it was within walking distance of our hotel so we thought that we would give it a try. I had recently visited my hometown zoo and so I was only going because my husband wanted to go. I really enjoyed my visit as I thought that there were a great variety of animals. All of the animals were healthy and in wonderful surroundings. Our favorite was seeing the 10 day old baby elephant and how the females were so protective of the little one. The entire zoo setting was lush with plants, shrubs, and trees. So glad that we visited this zoo!

Depressed Animals. I love zoos and have visited a few around the world.Artis Zoo is full of depressed animals either swaying, pacing, weaving........I felt emotionally upset after my day here. Theres the odd animals that look happy but the large animals are obviously depressed.Please dont go, I promise you will regret if you do......plus its a rip off.......twenty euros each. Spend your money on real Amsterdam and go to a good museum! Or spend it at a coffeeshop.

A Zoo to go and see. I am not a big fan of zoos because I do prefer to see animals in their natural habitat however, I have 2 young children and living in London we don't get to see animals roaming freely (other than pigeons and foxes). The price is high for adults and children however you can at least see where your money goes. The animals are well fed and maintained. Their enclosures are kept clean and they appear to have activitied available that suit their needs. It's designed with smaller people in mind, with viewing platforms at children height or glass sections where children can see into the enclosures. There are small trolleys that you can pay Euro 2 for and wheel the kids around in when their little feet get tired, so no need to take a pushchair (obviously for babies these wouldn't be recommended).There is a climbing frame for older children near one of the many restaurants and there is a fantastic butterfly enclosure which you can walk through and experience breathtaking butterflies, some even landing on people.All in all I would recommend the zoo.

A lot to see, but expensive prices and sad animals. Expensive, almost 20 euro to get in. While inside there's alot of animals to see and it takes a couple of hours before you've seen everything. Many animals live in too small cages though, and some looked very bored and restless. Since the price is so high they should really consider spending some of the money on the animals so they can get better living conditions.

fun for kids, miserable animals!. our daughter had a lot of fun, especially in the butterflies "room", but some animals were in too small places, even alone, without a companion.the entry fee is too expansive!!

Very surprised at this large and interesting zoo. Having read some reviews on here I thought i was going to a small zoo with cramped cages, it wasn't a thing like this. Large, open, hugely family friendly and loads to do. In addition to the usual there was a huge and impressive aquarium, much better than any sea life centre in the uk, a butterfly house, reptile house, insect house, planetarium and all sorts.A lovely day out in an impressive zoo, better than ny i have visited in the uk (london, edinburgh etc..)

A small Zoo but with lot's of animals. I am a big fan of animals, I have visited Zoo's all over the world and on several occassions i have been to Artis and I enjoyed it. I would prefer to see all animals walking in the wild, but the problem is we cant all afford to see them there, so then a zoo is an alternative. As for Artis Some animals do need new housing, basically this pnly goes for the big cats, but in the Zoo's defense i must say they are working on it, it is improving bit by bit (as I love big cat's i do however hope that they will move ahead soon). Having seen zoo's in Africa, Asia, North America and other parts I have seen better and i have seen worse. A Zoo in the centre of Amsterdam doesn't have as much space as for instance the Bronx Zoo, still the living conditions are much better than those of the Zoo in Antwerp... I enjoy it, but i do have to say in Holland there are bigger and in that sense better Zoo's. Overall it is an enjoyable afternoon and most animals do not seem stressed or limited by the space that they have.If you like animals, but do except that some are kept in enclosures (Zoo's) then you'll enjoy Artis. If you want wild animals to walk free don't go to any zoo!.If you prefer to see bigger Zoo's with bigger enclosures you can best go to the Zoo's in Arnhem, Rotterdam (also still bussy with improvements) or Hilvarenbeek.

ZOO Amsterdam. This is a great place to visit with kids and family. Very nice place in the downtown and I have to say great made and well maintained. You will see so many species of animals, bugs, skelets and you can spend one great afternoon down there.I was very impressed by the gorilaz.Great time in the ZOO

Would recommend. We went to the zoo on the last day of our trip. The price was a bit steep- 18.50E for each adult! After paying that, I thought this thing better be good- and it was! As another poster has mentioned "this is not an animal rights commentary." From a tourist's perspective this place was great! There are animals that do need a bigger enclosure, but there were also animals whose enclosures were fine and looked relatively happy.This was my first zoo visit in Europe. All the others have been in the U.S. I was surprised at how close you can get to some of the animals! They had a lot of animals I had never seen before. The aquarium and insect area were extra perks. If you have kids they are guaranteed to be entertained here! There is more than one play area for kids, other interactive activities, places to sit, more than one restaurant, etc.The tanks in the aquarium were overall clean from what I had seen. It clean, the staff were friendly, and the landscape was beautiful. Just wish we would have gotten a map free considering the price we paid! All of the signs were in English as well as Dutch so that was helpful. I would recommend it to others.

a zoo where the animals are ALIVE!!. We were near the Zoo in July 2010 on a Saturday afternoon expecting it to close at 6pm but on asking found it is open until 10pm on summer Saturdays. And we are glad we stumbled upon this gem!!!There is a summer programme of special events such as music, however many Amsterdam familes had brought picnics simply to sit in the green spaces and chat and chill outOne of the highlights is the Acquarium which is a sprawling grand old building with massive tanks showcasing exotic and fascinating specimensWhat really impressed us was that most of the animals were animated, unlike some Zoos where they are bored or asleep. There was a high amount of mating activity which fascinated our son!!! Best of all were the Giraffes - I have never seen a baby giraffe run round playfully - and the Elephants where the male and female were passionately nuzzling each otherWe were getting a bit hungry seeing all the Dutch familes tucking into their picknics and stumbled across the main cafe where an enthusiastic guy made us fresh filled baguettes - one ham one smoked salmon which we washed down with chilled beers, all at an reasonable priceThe entrance charge was about 50Euros for 2 adults and a child and was one of the most memorable things we saw in Amsterdam

Very entertaining for young kids.. I would say going to this zoo would be more of an all day visit as when you are walking about the zoo you will end up getting sore feet if you don't take breaks. But the terrain is so much better than Edinburgh zoo as it is situated on a hill so walking anywhere in Edinburgh zoo is a trek. I like to see aquariums so seeing the aquarium and zoological musuem was a treat. I liked walking into the zoo where you were greeted by camels and donkeys. When you walk further in you get to see all sorts of animals. I thought seeing the vultures were great as when we got to them they were feeding, so seeing the vultures feeding on what I thought was a bird. Overall, great variety of animals.Definately bring a camera, water and comfortable shoes.

Free these animals!!. Lets get straight to the facts of what i saw there, firstly i had heard good things about this zoo so was very intrigued in going. Only to find out the people who say its worth the visit, is either just hype, or they walked in with their eyes closed!! From start to finish was very very upsetting for me, to the point im actual hurt and traumatized from what i had seen. Firstly it IS expensive for what you get,...and what you get is quite upsetting. The cages/ space is waay too small. Especially for the lions and elephants that i saw there. Every animal i came across looked bored, so bored with their surrounding they almost looked like they were boarding on derangement, evidence of this was the lions walking up and down back and forth actually looking very sad and low because they had no activities to do, or enough space to do them in, so what else could they do in that tight space. One white wolf i saw was all alone and very sad, i could tell because it was actually whining non stop,.. aint they suppose to be in herds! More shocking was the elephants being so bored they were actually swaying from side to side, not in a playful way, more in a mesmerized demented way. Never in my years of going zoos have i seen anything like this. It really upset me. I think its time for the zoo to release these animals, because its obvious their not offering a good enough service to these animals, only just keeping them based more on entertainment values than anything else. ...What do i think?.....Anyone who goes here will be shocked, distraught (if they really do care for animals well-being like i do) and disappointed, and to be honest this place needs to be reported. (Plus i have evidence on my camera of this sad trip there).

Do not visit The Artis Zoo!. I was there the day before yesterday. I got more and more bad conscience have supported them financially.The animals had miserable conditions. Like so many of you write, the cages were too small. Many of them had no mate, which I think has made them both crazy and lonely. Many of them looked malnourished. The penguins had only a waterdepth of about 30 cm.I'm a grown man, but when I saw the bear I cried

Absolutely worth a visit!. Did a short visit during my stay in Amsterdam. The zoo is centrally located not far from the center of Amsterdam, and considering the space they have available, I think it's a very nice zoo, an absolutely worth a visit while in Amsterdam. The prices are also fair.

The kids will love it, big or small!. Although the zoo is limited on the large animals you might expect to see it's got plenty of smaller more unusual ones. Within walking distance of the centre it great for a half day visit. The kids loved it and it offers variety to a city break.

A great place to spend the afternoon. Before i went away i read all these terrible reviews of this zoo so i didant actually want to visit it, however we were staying just around the corner from it so we decided to go. I'm so glad we did because it was great! I agree that some of the animals enclosures might not have been the best but i think they might be going through the zoo and improving on this. The zoo was huge and had an aquarium as well. I think if you like zoos or if you have some spare time you should go check it out, especailly if you have children.

One word: Pass. This is not an animal rights commentary. Rather, from a tourist perspective I thought the entire complex was overpriced and underwhleming. Two dots instead of one for the half-decent aquarium. Let's start with the price: 2 adults and 1 child (age 10) for 52 Euros (appx $80 USD at the time we were there). Granted it was January so one can't expect a nice spring walk, but it had snowed the night before (just a coating to make slush) and the property is not staffed, or bothers to clean the walks. If you are open all year, I don't think it's unreasonable to clean the walks for your guests so they don't slip and parents with strollers don't have to struggle.Website advertised tours in English each Sunday at 11 AM. Not only was there no tour in English, this was the only place I've been to in the Netherlands where I received a look of nationalistic disgust when I asked about a tour in English.Planetarium ok: commentary in Dutch only which one can't fault them on--you can't exactly subtitle other languages in a planetarium. Aforementioned aquarium is brief but decent.Save your money if you are a tourist. Reminds me of one of those places in the US that kids go to on a field trip as a "throw away" day for the teacher.

Zoo is ok But really small Space for the animals.. Went Twice Aug 2007 & Oct 2009..Zoo Is ok,Gd for a half day out once you are in Amsterdam...but I feel sorry for the animals as the cages/spaces they live in are so small...on the other hand Butterflies are amazing!

Very Disappointed.. Took my nephews yesterday and left very unhappy with what I saw. In this day and age, when we know that animals are not unthinking, unfeeling beings, it is particularly disturbing that in a cosmopolitan city like Amsterdam, there are big cats still in small cages. Yes, there is some attempt at enrichment via trees and grass in the cages, but it is still unacceptably small and heartbreaking. Another generation of children will grow up thinking this is OK because their parents take them there and of course if the parents think this OK, their kids will too. If these animals are to give their lives for our education then the least we can do is make their lives as best as possible. Shame on Amsterdam a city I happen to love and with so much else to offer. Stay away if you have any love for animals.

So TERRIBLY sorry for the ANIMALS. Upon visiting the zoo the entrance was beautiful. However, my opinion changed quickly. All of the enclosures were much too small for the animals. I feel that the staff in charge need to travel the world and visit other zoos to see how animals should be housed. For instance, the zoo closest to my home is Brookfield Zoo in Brookfield Illinois right outside of Chicago.(USA) At least there you could see the attempt is being made to allow the animals proper housing. Overall the staff at this zoo were very helpful and pleasant, but the enclosures need to be larger. I feel they need to close the zoo down and enlarge the area. Whatever it takes, afterall, it is about these creatures.

Wonderful attraction with small children. Been to zoos all over, this was by far the best one. Was able to see animals we've never seen before (hippos and zebras). There are play areas all over the place, an aquarium, and a planetarium. Enjoyed the hot food in the African restaurant. The butterfly experience was AMAZING!

zoo. When visiting Amsterdam even without children the zoo is a fantasitc place to visit. It can be found in the Plantage area of Amsterdam on the tram line number 9 and 12. It is also only 10 minute walk from the Rambrandt square. The entrance cost is 17.50 Euro with 1 Euro reduction for Seniors over 65. It is also 13.50 Euro after 3.30pm. There are lots of animals to see including Jaguars, Gorillas, Elephants and Giraffes. Lots of lovely places to sit and soak up the sun as well. Well worth a visit even the children seemed really well behaved with no screaming.

Artis a zoo of torture. I took my family to Artis this week, on the understanding it was one of Europes best Zoo's, I couldn't have been more wrong. First impression good (from the outside).The amimals are in cages far too small, 8 lions in one cage! Birds in cages that are too small to permit fight!The enclosures for the reptiles are strewn with faeces.The final straw was the Polar Bear, small dirty pit, with barely enough water for it too stand in, let alone swim. This was a pittyfull and upsetting sight. We stopped here and left.Please don't visit this Zoo, if you do, you are encouraging animal suffering. Don't submit your Children as I did, to these horrific sights.In this day and age no animal deserves to suffer, Uk Zoo's and Safari Parks would never get away with conditions like these.

almost cried my eyes out!. I visited artis zoo last week with my family and after walking the entire length of amsterdam thought that it was gonna be fab, on first impression as we walked into the zoo it seemed nice enough as there is a very nice entrance, that's about it! The animal enclosures were very small, there were six lions in an enclosure that can.t have been much bigger than my living room with very little shade and they looked bored out of their minds. As we walked around it became apparant the this was becoming a familiar sight with most of the animals, the sea lion tank was very small and must have had at least six inches of something growing on the bottom it was disgusting even my seven year old daughter noticed how bad that was, we had only been in the zoo for about an hour and a half by the time we got to the polar bear and i was very excited to see it because they are very difficult to keep in captivity as is well known , when I saw her it broke my heart, she was in a old style victorian enclosure where you look down on her, she had very little water, it was stinking, she was under nourished and she just paced from side to side with the sun in her eyes looking totally mad! I'm not a major animal welfare freak (no offence) but this really upset me and i feel that they should be shut down, who on earth governs the welfare of these poor animals? Are they blind? I really think my 54 euros for us to go in could be put to better use than blatent animal cruelty! You would never see that kind of care in a well run british zoo!

A Great Day Out In Amsterdam. We went to the zoo weds morning by tram from Centraal station,line 9.We bought a tram saver strip for 6.8euro covering 3 of us.Entry was 16.2euro after a discount.The zoo was very clean and had a great array of animals,including a gorgeous black panther.There was a great reptile house and monkey house.Lunch was very reasonably priced in a modern restaurant with very clean toilets.Staff were very helpfull and happy to discuss the animals.Altogether a very happy experience and highly recommended,especially if you have children,for which there were plenty of activities and numerous climbing frames.There is also a very good aquarium with a crocodile pit.I have been to Paris zoo and this is superior,although Paris is only 5euros.Enjoy,Terry.

My best short break. Myself and my husband have visited amsterdam and artis zoo on a few occasions now and it is just as enjoyable as the first time.The people are friendly the places are clean and i love the shopping,although i dont think my husband likes that much,we are planning a visit at the end of october for christmas shopping.quality time together and cant wait to come, the only problem ,is we have to come home.Great place lots to see and do and lovely to sit in dam square and watch the world go by.

Depressing. I went with my boyfriend to the Artis Zoo on our last trip to Amsterdam. I was so disappointed. The big cats (lions etc) were pacing up and down their small enclosures looking very depressed. The sealions were in such small pools too. Some elephants were rocking back and forth and the wolves did not seem very happy either. The animals areas are not any where near big enough for them.It is a lovely looking Zoo but I would not go again and I certainly above anything else would not recommend it to anyone, especially anyone who loves animals.On the plus side the staff spoke all different languages as you would expect at a major tourist attraction and were happy and helpful. Just a shame about the animals. :(I took pictures whilst I was there so if anyone would like to see them then I would be happy to help. It was not a pleasant trip and I will not be going to the Zoo again.

Depressing. After reading some of the reviews before our trip we were unsure as to wheather we should visit the zoo. As it was the last day of our trip, the weather was nice and we had visited all the major sites we thought we would pay the zoo a visit. We decided to walk from our hotel which was opposite central station, this took about 15 mins.It cost around 14 Euros to get in, once we were in there was lots of see and do. Some of the animals, Polar bear and Hippo in particular were in a confined area and the poor polar bear was pacing up and down, looking very bored. The Hippo was in a tiny indoor pool, which didnt look very deep, they may of had him in there while they were cleaning his outside area,who knows.When i saw this poor animals in tiny enclosures i felt guilty for visiting. I wouldnt recommend it to animal lovers.

Sad and heartbreaking. Almost ruined my trip - nearly cried at the polar bear who looks like he's lost his marbles, pacing and swaying in continuous circles, and the gorilla that just wanted to hide away but there was nowhere to go. Big cats, tiny barred cages. I normally don't mind zoo's - most do great conservation work, but this just seemed to be everything it shouldn't be. I'd never go back.

Good and BAD!. The zoo was nice but there were some animals that did not have big enough enclosures such as the Lions and other 'big cats'. The Polar bear was the saddest as she paced up and down in the same place for ages, her enclosure looked really small and she seemed like she was going out of her mind. It was sad to see and even my kids were not impressed!

a heartbreaking zoo visit. My husband and I took our children to Artis during the summer of 2006 and it was a huge disappointment. As in previous comments, the polar bear was a heartbreaking sight. Just lying on top of brown soil / wood chips etc. Is that really what the Arctic looks like? The hippo was housed in a concrete tank that was only just larger than he was. The aquarium was dingy and the fish tanks just looked dirty. Our overall feeling was that the zoo was definitely showing its age and seemed very neglected. It was hard to feel that the animals were enjoying their enclosures, as they bore no resemblance to their natural habitats. Surely it would be in both the best interest of the animals, as well as that of the visiting public for the facilities to be upgraded. I appreciate the zoo is in the middle of a city, but it is not a positive experience to see animals cramped in old, dingy, concrete enclosures, as the last thing they seem to be is happy.

Good apart from the polar bear. The zoo over all was ok, bigger and cleaner then what I expected! The bad things about this zoo were the fact they had crammed too many lions into a small enclosure, and worse of all the polar bear was just lying on the grass, in the burning sun!!! He didn't have much room, and his enclosure looked dirty!Apart from that the zoo was great, all the other animals looked happy.

Avoid if you're an animal lover. The zoo was full a whole range of animals, lots of them looked very sad. Could not get the poor polar bear out of my head, he spent at least 10 minutes just walking backwards and forwards in his granite enclosure.Not what I was expecting :-(

Home is where the Artis. Having only visited American zoos before, I wasn't filled with great hope for a small Dutch 'equivalent' - you know how the States claims to do things bigger and better than anywhere else!However, it is a truly amazing place. You can get really close to the vast array of animals, nip in and out of doors and buildings, from one landscape to another. Watching the penguins and sea lions being fed was utterly enjoyable - even in the below zero temperatures of early January!Furthermore, the ticket is great value for money (16 euros for adults) as it gets you into not only the zoo but also the planetarium, aquarium and geological museum.All in all, it's a great day out - with a new experience, creature, or image round every corner.

My day of fun!!!!. I visited the zoo for my 21st Birthday, and it was my highlight of the trip!!!! It's much better than it looks and had more animals than I had expected, including gorillas, penguins, ant eaters and many African cats.On top of all that, was the aquarium, again it had some amazing creatures including seahorses and catfish and many of the fish from "Finding Nemo".Another highlight was feeding times for the animals, really good idea.We went in November, so it wasn't over crowded at all.
